item.title: RabbitMQ
item.description: _______________ < Im not rabbit!! > --------------- \ ^__^ \ (oo)\_______ (__)\ )\/\ ||----w | || || Today at work in order to demonstrate a proof of concept (POC) related to message queues, had to spin up a rabbitmq server. “Play with Docker” come to the rescue. In couple of minutes environment is up and ready. docker run -d \ --hostname rabbit-host \ --name rabbit-container \ -p 80:15672 \ -p 5672:5672 \ -e RABBITMQ_DEFAULT_USER="rabbit" \ -e RABBITMQ_DEFAULT_PASS="carrot" \ rabbitmq:3-management PORT Description 15672 RabbitMQ Management console uses PORT 15672 for RabbitMQ version 3.

item.title: Play with docker
item.description:
Prerequisite Make sure you have already created a Docker Hub account. PWD This post is about “Play with Docker” chrome-extension. Play with Docker(PWD) by itself is a simple, interactive and fun playground to learn Docker. This will give you a throwaway *nix shell, in which you can safely play with docker.
Extension adds a “Try in PWD” button on any Docker Hub image page. Here is a short demo of same.

item.title: CURL
item.description: As part of my journey as a developer and decision to document my learning, I’ve been thinking of writing a short post regarding curl, here it is. Curl is a command line tool for transferring data to and from a server. Curl stands for Client URL and was developed by a Swedish developer Daniel Stenberg @bagder. It covers many protocols like HTTP, FTP, IMAP, POP3 & SMTP, It usually comes pre-installed in most of Linux distros and modern versions of OS X.
